[[File:Candye Kane 2012.jpg|thumb|308px|Candye Kane in Stockholm 2012]]

'''Candye Kane''' (born November 13, 1965)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.candyekane.com/meetcandye.html |title=Meet |publisher=Candye Kane |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> is an American singer, songwriter and [[performer]] best known in the [[blues]] and [[jazz]] genre.<ref>Although she has also recorded country western songs and is mentioned in several guides to California Country music.</ref> She has been included in the ''Rolling Stone Guide to Jazz and Blues'', ''Elwoods Blues'' by [[Dan Aykroyd]], ''The Blueshound Guide to Blues'', ''Allmusic'' and other blues books and periodicals. She also had a brief career as a pornographic actress during porn's [[Golden Age of Porn|golden age]].<ref>[http://www.tonic.com/article/candye-kane-a-blues-singer-with-a-past/ Candye Kane: A Blues Singer With a Past | Tonic – Inspiring News Stories & Social Good]. Tonic.com (June 30, 2008).</ref><ref>[http://www.lanasbigboobs.com/models/c/candye_kane Candye Kane Big Tit Pictures, Movies and Biography!]. Lanasbigboobs.com (November 13, 1965).</ref>

==Early life==
Kane was born in [[Ventura, California]] and raised in [[Highland Park, Los Angeles|Highland Park]], a Los Angeles suburb.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanasbigboobs.com/models/c/candye_kane/ |title=Candye Kane Big Tit Pictures, Movies and Biography! |publisher=Lanasbigboobs.com |date=1965-11-13 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

==Music career==
She was accepted into the [[University of Southern California|USC]]'s music conservatory's junior opera program in 1976 but disliked opera and dropped out. She became part of the [[punk rock]] music scene of the early 1980s. She started [[Alt country|country punk]] bands and befriended and shared the stage with musicians as diverse as [[Black Flag (band)|Black Flag]], [[Social Distortion]], [[James Harman]], [[The Circle Jerks]], [[Los Lobos]], [[The Blasters]] and [[Lone Justice]].<ref name="ameriblues1">{{cite web|author=Administrator |url=http://www.ameriblues.com/2011/03/07/12236/ |title=Candye Kane Blues Music Award Nominee — American Blues News |publisher=Ameriblues.com |date=2011-03-07 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> In 1985, she caught the attention of CBS/Epic A&R Head, Larry Hanby. She was signed to a developmental deal and recorded her first demo with Grammy Winner [[Val Garay]]. Kane was initially marketed as a country singer but CBS dropped her when they found out about her controversial past.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/bands/candye-kane/ |title=Candye Kane |publisher=San Diego Reader |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> At 17 she got pregnant with her first son. When she turned 18 she turned to adult modeling and stripping to make some cash, appearing in videos and over 150 magazines from 1983 to 1985. Eventually she worked as a columnist for [[Gent (magazine)|''Gent'' magazine]] as well.

In 1986, she moved from Los Angeles to [[San Diego]]. She married bass player Thomas Yearsley (of [[rockabilly]] power trio [[The Paladins]]) with whom she had another son.
She majored in [[women's studies]] at Palomar Community College. She continued to write songs and accidentally discovered the brash blues stylings of [[Big Maybelle]], [[Ruth Brown]], [[Big Mama Thornton]], [[Etta James]] and [[Bessie Smith]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|last=Carone |first=Angela |url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2011/jan/20/candye-kane-toughest-girl-alive/ |title=Candye Kane Is The Toughest Girl Alive |publisher=KPBS.org |date=2011-01-20 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

In 1991, she self-released ''[[Burlesque Swing]],'' her first recording since ''[[A Town South of Bakersfield]]''. In 1992 was signed by [[Clifford Antone]] to a record deal with ''Antones Records''. Her first CD, "Home Cookin'" was produced by [[Cesar Rosas]] (of [[Los Lobos]]) and [[Hacienda Brothers|Dave Gonzales]] and Thomas Yearsley (of the Paladins). It was released in 1992 followed by ''[[Knock Out (Candye Kane album)|Knock Out]]''. She then signed with [[Discovery Records]] releasing ''[[Diva La Grande]]'', produced by [[Dave Alvin]] and [[Derek O'Brien (guitarist)|Derek O'Brien]]. Next, she was signed by record mogul [[Seymour Stein]] to Sire Records during the height of the swing revival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/candye-kane/discography/131334/ |title=Swango by Candye Kane |publisher=MTV |date=1998-08-18 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

She released ''[[Swango (album)|Swango]]'' which was produced by [[Mike Vernon (producer)|Mike Vernon]] for ''Sire/London Records'' (her only major label debut to date.) This was followed by Kane's ''Rounder/Bullseye'' release, ''[[The Toughest Girl Alive]]'' produced by [[Scott Billington]]. Next she released four CDs on the German Label [[Ruf Records]]. Subsequent titles include ''Whole Lotta Love'' produced by [[Val Garay]] and ''[[White Trash Girl]]''<ref name="allmusic1">{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Hal |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/white-trash-girl-mw0000343630 |title=White Trash Girl - Candye Kane : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2005-06-07 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> produced in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] by Ruf Records and Mark Kazanoff.<ref name="allmusic1"/> In 2007, she released ''Guitar'd and Feathered'' on the RUF records label. The CD was produced by former Muddy Waters guitarist, Bob Margolin. In 2009, she signed to Delta Groove records and released ''Superhero'' in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Hal |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/superhero-mw0000819137 |title=Superhero - Candye Kane : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

A stage play about Kane's life debuted at San Diego's Diversionary Theatre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diversionary.org/ |title=Diversionary Theatre > Fresh, fun and fabulous |publisher=Diversionary.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> in January 2009, directed by Javier Velasco. The play is called ''The Toughest Girl Alive'' and is based on Kane's memoir about her turbulent life.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>

She was included on the ''30 Essential Women of the Blues'' CD set released by the House of Blues record label and the ''Rock for Choice'' compilation. She appears with [[Lucinda Williams]] and [[Dwight Yoakam]] on a ''Town South of Bakersfield'' on [[Enigma Records]].

==Songwriting==
Kane has written songs such as "The Toughest Girl Alive" (used on the ''[[Hidden Palms]]'' series for the CW network);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rLtneEXSlTA |title=Hidden Palms Sezon 01 odc. 7 Część 4 PL |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-01-11 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> "Who Do You Love", which was nominated for an OUT music award; "200 Pounds of Fun" (featured in the motion picture, ''The Girl Next Door''); "For Your Love" (included on an episode of ''[[The Chris Isaak Show]]''); "Please Tell Me a Lie" (used in the motion picture ''Heavy'', starring [[Deborah Harry]]);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113280/soundtrack?ref_=tt_trv_snd|title=Heavy (1995) Soundtracks|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> "You Need a Great Big Woman" (used on the Oxygen Network series ''[[Strong Medicine]]''); "The Lord was a Woman" (recorded by comedienne [[Judy Tenuta]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesprofiles.com/Bios/Candye%20Kane.htm |title=Candye Kane |publisher=Bluesprofiles.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

==Current career and touring==
Her eighth CD, released in May 2007, was titled ''Guitar’d and Feathered''. Kane is now signed to Los Angeles's [[Delta Groove Productions|Delta Groove]] records. She tours worldwide more than 250 days a year. She has appeared on many prestigious festivals including the [[Ascona Jazz Festival]], [[Midem]], [[Paléo Festival]], [[Monterey Jazz Festival]], [[Dubai International Jazz Festival]], [[Waterfront Blues Festival]], [[Notodden Blues Festival]] among others. She has played for the [[President of Italy]] at the French Embassy in Rome and at the [[Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="advocate1">{{cite web|last=Anderson |first=Diane |url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/music/2011/10/05/bisexual-blues-singer-candye-kane-brings-sexy-back |title=Bisexual Blues Singer Candye Kane Brings Sexy Back |publisher=Advocate.com |date=2011-10-05 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> Her music is often featured on [[B. B. King's Bluesville]] on XM radio.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marshall |first=Matt |url=http://www.americanbluesscene.com/2012/01/candye-kane-battling-cancer-a-second-time/ |title=Candye Kane Battling Cancer a Second Time |publisher=Americanbluesscene.com |date=2012-01-20 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

==Awards==
2011: Candye Kane is nominated for two Blues Foundation – 2012 Blues Music Awards:
BB King Entertainer of the Year & Best Contemporary Blues Female.

Kane was nominated for four [[Blues Music Awards]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blues.org/#ref=index |title=The Blues Foundation |publisher=Blues.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref> for the BB King Entertainer of the Year Award, Best Contemporary Blues CD for Superhero, and Best Contemporary Blues Female of 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blues.org |title=The Blues Foundation |publisher=Blues.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref> She has won numerous awards, including the Best Blues Band award at the [[San Diego Music Awards]] seven times.

Other recent honors include Best Blues CD of 2005 at the [[San Diego Music Awards]]; the [[Trophees France International Award]] 2004 for Best International Blues Chanteuse and Artist of the Year. She unseated [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]] for Artist of the Year at the San Diego Music Awards and won the [[California Music Award]] for Best Swing-Cabaret Artist. In May 2007, Kane won an award for Best Original Blues composition by the [[West Coast Songwriters Association]] for her song, "I'm My Own Worst Enemy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westcoastsongwriters.org/sites/default/files/newsletters/May07.pdf |title=JUNE047.0 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref> In 2012, Miss Kane received a special Courage in Music Award at the San Diego Music Awards ceremonies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/aug/13/surprises-upsets-san-diego-muasic-awards/ |title=Surprises, upsets at San Diego Music Awards Page 1 of 3 |publisher=UTSanDiego.com |date=2012-08-14 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

In 2014, Kane was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'Contemporary Blues Female Artist of the Year' category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Kane has two grown sons, one of whom, Evan Caleb, played drums in her road band.<ref name="ameriblues1"/> She appears often at [[gay pride]] festivals worldwide and identifies openly as a [[bisexual]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Candye Kane's bodacious blues|first=Brad|last=Wheeler|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20070712.BLUES12/TPStory/TPEntertainment/Music|date=July 12, 2007|accessdate=2007-07-16|work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada}}</ref> Kane has become an activist and philanthropist in recent years. In August 2009, she appeared in Dublin, Ireland for the World Congress for Downs Syndrome with her United by Music charity.<ref name="advocate1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deltagrooveproductions.com/music/artists/candye_kane/main.html |title=The Delta Groove Family: Candye Kane |publisher=Deltagrooveproductions.com |accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>

In March 2008, Kane revealed on her website that she has been diagnosed with [[pancreatic cancer]] and was undergoing treatment. The tumor was found to be a [[neuroendocrine tumor]] and was successfully resected on April 18, 2008 at UCSD Medical Center/Thornton Hospital.<ref>{{Citation|title=Candye Kane – News|url=http://www.candyekane.com/news.html|date=March 27, 2008|accessdate=2008-04-05}}</ref>
